Phiroz Vandrevala, Head of Global Corporate Affairs
Ajoy Mukherjee, Vice President & Head, Global Human Resources

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and good evening. I am Rochelle, the moderator for this conference call. Welcome to the TCS Earnings Conference. Please note that for the duration of this presentation, all participant lines will be in the listen-only mode and this conference is being recorded. After the presentation, there will be an opportunity for you to ask questions.
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. David Nelson, Head of Global Investor Relations. Thank you, and over to you, Mr. Nelson.

Rochelle, thank you very much. Good evening and welcome everyone and thank you for joining us on the TCS Earnings Call for Quarter One Fiscal Year 2009. As Rochelle said, I am David Nelson, Head of Global Investor Relations for TCS.

Please note that this call is being webcast through our website and an archive, including transcript, will be available on the site for the duration of the quarter. The financial statements, results presentation and press releases are also available on our website.
Our leadership team is present on this call to discuss our results. We have with us Mr. Ramadorai, Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director.
Good evening, everyone.
Mr. Mahalingam, Chief Financial Officer.
Good evening, good morning.
Mr. Chandrasekaran, Chief Operating Officer.
Good evening and good morning, everyone.
Mr. Phiroz Vandrevala, Head of Global Corporate Affairs.
Good morning, good evening, everybody.
And Mr. Ajoy Mukherjee, Head of Global Human Resources.
Hi, everyone.
Ramchandra and Maha will all begin with a brief overview of the company's performance, followed by a Q&A session.

As you are aware, TCS does not provide specific revenue and earnings guidance. Furthermore, anything said on this call which reflects our outlook for the future, or which can be construed as a forward-looking statement, must be viewed in conjunction with the risks that the company faces. These risks are outlined in the second slide of our results presentation.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Ramadorai to begin the proceedings.

Thank you, Dave. And again, good morning, good evening. The new financial year has been challenging one so far. Global macroeconomic factors, including the ongoing problems in the global financial sector, rising oil prices and the threat of recession in some developed markets have had an impact on large global corporations, leading to uncertainty and general caution all around.

Despite facing this macro level situation and other client-specific challenges, I am happy to announce that TCS has grown its business in quarter one. Quarter one revenue was at INR64,107 million, has grown over 24% on a year-on-year basis, and this translates into 6% growth sequentially.

As you are aware, we have rolled out our new customer-centric organization structure in this quarter. We are extremely pleased with the alignment and efficiency achieved. Our performance in quarter one demonstrates the underlying strength of our business model and highlights our value proposition to our customers. This is evident in the strength shown by our international business, which has essentially grown at 7%. Each of the major markets, North America, U.K. and Europe grew in excess of 6% individually, and collectively they have grown at 8% sequentially, higher than the company average. New growth markets have grown at a slower pace, partly because they are cyclical in nature like India.

Turnkey. Our diversified vertical strategy is also helping us in the current uncertain climate. A negative demand impact from some of our BFSI clients in this quarter, for instance, has been made up by increased orders from customers in other sectors. But manufacturing, retail and life sciences are also proceeding, as we planned. We are managing our business mix to compensate for any fall in demand due to customer-specific problems, and Chandra after this will provide more color on these aspects of the business.

From a TCS perspective, what is also important in today's challenging environment is to take control of the circumstances that are within the company's zone of influence. For instance, there has been a need to focus on cost controls, to ensure that we are doing everything we can to manage costs and become much more efficient at running the business.

In this respect, we have embarked on a strong program of cost control that have helped us to reduce our SG&A expenses from the quarter four levels by 217 basis points as a percentage of revenue. This is despite planned wage increases being factored in during quarter one.

TCS has also crossed another billion dollar milestone this quarter. Despite the uncertainties, we continue to generate cash and we have over $1 billion in terms of cash in hand. Given the circumstances, this will be a competitive advantage for TCS going forward as it expands its operations across the globe.

We continue to dialogue with our customers and communicate our value proposition and our agility and focus on an ongoing basis. We believe we'll be generating demand in the coming quarters. I would also like to add that there is still uncertainty in the environment and this could result into issues for specific companies.

Having said all of the above, there is a demand for IT services, and there are opportunities therefore for growth. We continue to hire people as planned and invest for the future. Overall, cost efficiencies, continued focus on retention of customers and demonstration of our value proposition in challenging times will be the theme for the immediate future.
I will hand over to Chandra now.
Thank you, Ram. Hello, everyone. I would like to explain the key aspects of the operational performance during the quarter.

Specifically, I would like to provide some commentary on the operating conditions in four different areas, namely the BFSI segment, what is happening, and what happened in Q1. And growth in the major markets of the US, UK, Europe and emerging markets, how we're seeing it, what has been our experience in Q1; also, the different industry portfolio, the pricing environment in general, and what they expect going forward.

Now, coming to the BFSI segment, when we had this call during the last quarter, we mentioned that there are two specific lines that we are facing issues and we are likely to see the revenues drop. We did have material impacts in revenues coming down in those two clients during the quarter one.

Then we have one large banking client, who is going through a de-merger process to a consortium of banks in U.K., Latin America and Europe. And while we managed to get the same revenues from the client in the business as usual committed area, the discretionary spend and revenues due to that came down during quarter one.

The third aspect is we also had a revenue dip in the products business, primarily because some of the decision-making got delayed in the product business. So these three contributed to revenue drops in our banking and financial services sector. We made a vast majority of this drop by ramping up with our clients some of the deals we announced in the banking sector, and the net result is the drop you see in the, we will say, as a percentage of overall revenue.

Then coming to the major markets, the U.S.A., U.K. and Europe together grew substantially, 2.2% in dollar terms during the quarter. And this must be seen in light of the BFSI hit I talked about. That BFSI hit happened in the major markets and we managed to compensate for that and still achieve a 2.2% of dollar term growth in these markets.

Coming to the organization, we rolled out the new organization this quarter. As Ram said, we are very happy with the way it is has gone. In the new organization, we created a special unit called the Industries Solutions Unit, which is predominantly to serve the key clients across verticals in the major markets, and this unit posted a revenue growth of 9.9%. So that has worked extremely well for us.

Then coming to the emerging markets or the new growth markets, we had hit in both India as well as in Latin America. In India, it is a cyclical market and we had a revenue drop in absolute terms in Q1 compared to Q4. Then in Latin America, we got impacted significantly because of the discretionary spend coming now and the revenues going down with the banking client, who is going through the demerger I talked about. And so, the overall growth you see, the 6% in rupee terms, has primarily come from the major markets. Not only the Latin America and India have not grown, they have taken a revenue dip, so that must be seen in that light.

And coming to pricing, the pricing environment has been generally stable. We have had some contract renewals, and we have not had price cuts in any one of those contracts. They have been stable. And the drop in pricing you see in this quarter is primarily due to two factors. Our transformation project has come to an end; it is reflected in the overall fixed price revenues going down this quarter, and the product-related revenues have contributed low this quarter. And those two have affected the drop in pricing, and we see it is a one-off this quarter.

Now, coming to the future, of the three client scenarios I talked about, the two clients which I articulated during the Q4 and the banking client which is going through the demerger. Today, these three clients, we have turned the corner with two of them and we expect incremental revenues and growth during Q2 with two of those clients. With the third client, there is going to be a hit during .

The deal pipeline, we did close twelve large deals during the quarter in Q1, three of them in the 75 to $100 million range. And going forward, our deal pipeline is healthy. We have a pipeline of 20 qualified large deals currently we are pursuing, and a good number of that are in the banking and financial services sector also. If you see the deal wins that we have announced, we have announced some deal wins even in the BFSI segment.

Our performance in the manufacturing sector and retail sector has been very satisfying. They have grown significantly during Q1, and we continue to see growth in manufacturing, retail and utilities and high-tech sectors in the coming quarters. There are a large number of opportunities in these sectors with regard to bringing in sourcing optimization and transformation.
With regard to telecom, we see growth opportunities in the equipment sector in the developed markets, and system integration and transformation engagements in the developing markets.

Overall, I would like to add that the environment especially in the financial services sector is uncertain. So, we have to look for any specific client-related situations that can happen and we've got to proactively address that. Otherwise, we remain very confident about growth in the coming quarters.
Thank you, and over to Mark.

Thanks, Chandra. I will cover the results for the quarter, a couple of accounting changes and some details regarding our foreign exchange program. As we go through these, I would like you to keep in mind two key points. First, in these times of slower growth and market uncertainty, a strong focus should be on driving operational efficiency and cost containment. As you know, this is a position, TCS has growth – the growth pattern as the business picks up.
Second, our Forex program is performing as designed. Our Forex program is essentially the insurance program which protects our downside risk while allowing upside benefits.

Before I discuss Q1 financials, I would like to walk you – walk you through a couple of changes in reporting. TCS is taking this opportunity at the start of new fiscal year to switch to reporting US GAAP and US dollar instead of Indian rupee.

First, this change will help facilitate the understanding of TCS financials by global investors. Second, US dollar statements will provide investors with a better understanding of the health of the underlying business. As you know, approximately 50% of our business is based in the US and denominated in US dollars.

To smooth the transition from Indian rupee to US dollar, we've published a US GAAP statement denominated in Indian rupee as well as in US dollars for this quarter. Prior to the earnings call for Q2 results, we will make available the historical quarter financial statements in US dollars. This should facilitate the reconstruction of the financial models by the analysts. Additionally, this change will also necessitate a change in how we account for the cash flow hedges that have been previously recorded in the revenue line. With a change to US dollar US GAAP statements, all gains and losses from hedging will be recorded in other income expenses.

Finally, we are making a change in the method of calculating the depreciation of computer assets effective this financial year. In order to align TCS factors with the actual computer you are using and also with warranty of images and software by vendors, we will begin depreciating these assets over four years instead of two years. This has resulted in an overall reduction of approximately INR497 million or 67 basis points in depreciation expense this quarter.

Now let us look at the income statement. The revenue increased 6.02% Q-on-Q and 24.8% Y-on-Y in rupee term; 0.5% and 20.8% respectively in US dollar terms. Chandra has already covered in detail what is driving the revenue growth and revenue performance. The following growing the breakdown of revenue growth quarter-over-quarter: volume, 1.3% increase, pricing, 90 basis point decline, effort mix, 50 basis point increase – this is a shift from offshore to on-site, foreign exchange 5.1%. Total revenue increased 6.02%.

Operating margin stayed roughly in line with the previous quarter in spite of absorbing rate increases that impacted margins by 196 basis points. The breakdown of various items that impacted margins quarter-over-quarter are as follows: Q4 '08 operating margin was 22.32%, SG&A efficiency gave us 2.17% positive. Forex impact, 2.3% positive, wage impact, 1.96% negative. Pricing and productivity is 2.94% negative, on-site shift 0.17% negative. Total negative of .26% and therefore, Q1 '09's operating margin was 22.06%.
Overall, SG&A for the quarter came down by INR580 million in spite of adverse impact of rupee depreciation. In terms of percentage of revenue, SG&A came down to 19.99% in Q1 compared to 22.16% in Q4.

We have a comprehensive cost containment program. On the one hand, this program focuses on conducting our projects more efficiently and managing manpower results better. You will see the impact of this part of the program over the balance of the year, in areas such as improved utilization and increased offshore leverage. Additionally, we have also carefully been scrutinizing and tackling our non-salary cost structures. We have taken several proactive steps to reduce these cost structures, focusing on a number of areas, such as travel, power consumption and IT and communication costs.

Quarter-over-quarter, these non-salary costs, excluding depreciation of equipment and software costs, actually declined by INR400 million. Adding back the negative impact of rupee depreciation on these non-rupee costs, the total decline would have been INR760 million. The cost containment program, as we can see, is working. Then examining net income, margins declined by 137 basis points largely attributable to a reduction in other income of 143 basis points Rupees in 'Q4 FY 2008. This was partially offset by a tax credit repeat from an overseas geography.

I would now like to take a closer look at our foreign exchange hedge program. Total net foreign exchange losses booked in our income statement for Q1 was 753 million or approximately US$18 million. This loss was booked to other income stock expenses as a net foreign exchange loss.

I would like to take a few moments to clarify some of the descriptions related to foreign exchange hedge programs. The basic philosophy of our hedge program is to protect foreign future earnings at certain rates without sacrificing the ability to benefit on the upside. I think it is best to look at our hedge program as an insurance program, which protects downside risk by allowing us to benefit from the upside. The first question is, what do we hedge? We have a regular program that hedges existing risk, existing receivables and net revenue as well as future risks, net project revenue. All the existing risks and hedges against these risks are mark-to-market every quarter and the gains and losses are recorded in other income expense.

Second, in addition to these hedges of existing receivables, we also hedge future revenue from specific projects. These hedges are undertaken to protect the future profitability of these projects and can extend to over next three to four – four to five years.

These contracts are also mark-to-market every quarter and the gains and losses from mark-to-market are recorded in other comprehensive income on the balance sheet. Since these contracts hedge future revenue, then it is prudent, both from a business and accounting perspective to match the impact of these hedges with the risk being hedged and to keep gains and losses on these contracts and balance sheets and the actual realization of the revenues.

The next question is, how do we hedge? That's that we protect downside risk when the rupee on the upside. We hedge our exposures through a combination of forward contracts and options contracts, with a substantial portion in options. This combination allows us to protect our downside risk of rupee appreciation, while at the same time to protect the upside of rupee depreciation. The dynamics of our hedging program is clearly seen over this past year. During the sharp rupee appreciation during FY 2008, we had a significant Forex gain, largely offsetting the losses that occurred as a result of depreciation – as a result of the appreciation.

On the other hand, in spite of strong depreciation of the currency during this past quarter, we have been able to participate in approximately 65% of the benefits. For the balance of the year, we will be able to participate on 80% of the exposure.

As I mentioned about, the mark-to-market of the cash flow hedge program is according to other comprehensive income. Additionally, we record here option premium expense associated with cash flow, hedge options maturing at a future date. The Q1 imbalance in other comprehensive income is a loss of INR4.08 billion. However, it is important to note that this among the strongest to impact the income statement and also that any impact of the income statement will be spread over probably eight to 10 quarters.

The final amount of direct gain or loss that will impact the income statement will ultimately depend on the exchange rate at that time the contract actually matures. For example, if the rate does not move from the current rate of 43, then the actual effect will only be INR1.686 billion, spread over primarily eight to 10 quarters and not INR4.08 billion. The difference between these numbers has to do with the required percent of -- contracts to market. The existing contracts have been marked-to-market at an average rate of 45.

In this scenario of constant rate of 43, at least 52% of INR1.36 billion would actually be recorded in FY 2009 income statement, based as follows: INR505 million in Q2; INR213 million in Q3; and INR200 million in Q4. And if we receive of the interest 43, then you would be translating that revenue at better rates. If, on the other hand, the rupee appreciates, we have downside protection as you saw with the large Forex gains that we realized last year.

Therefore, all current risks and hedges associated with these risks of mark-to-market every quarter-end in the income statement. In the event of the rupee depreciation, we participated nearly 80% on the upside. Mark-to-market of cash flow hedges at INR45 level is for INR4.08 billion. At the existing level of 43, the figure is only 1.686 billion, spread over 8 to 10 quarters.

In closing, it is clear that we are operating in a difficult environment. It is therefore critical that we drive operational efficiency and contain our cost structures, so that we can better position TCS as business improves over the year. We'll continue to build throughout the year on the success that you see in Q1. Thank you.
Rochelle, we'll now take questions from the participants.

Thank you very much, Mr. Nelson. Ladies and gentlemen, we will now begin the question-and-answer session. The first question is from the line of Ms. Diviya Nagarajan from JM Financial. Please go ahead.

Hi. You spoke about two or three clients actually turning around the corner during the quarter, and the third client actually getting a hit in the 2Q as well. Do you think the extent of the hit would be as significant as what you've seen with these two clients in the first quarter, or do you expect that to be any different?

Yes, I talked about three clients, of which I said two clients are turning around because – turning the corner and we are expecting to grow this quarter. And the third client, the extent of the hit is smaller compared to the hit that we have had in Q1.

Okay. So basically, what drives the confidence of growth in BFSI going forward? Who will contribute to the growth, do you see the clients that you have erstwhile seen not performing and giving you hits actually as contributing to growth as well or do you expect them to remain flat at current levels?
As I said, there are three factors which have contributed to the decline in revenues, because it's not about only growth.
No, I am talking specific to BFSI.

Yes. With respect to BFSI, there are three factors which contributed to the issues in Q1. One is these two clients I talked about in Q4. The second one is the banking client who is going through the demerger, the third one is the product revenues came down substantially from Q4 to Q1.

Now, looking at our pipeline, we see definitive growth in these two clients, out of the three. And in the third client, we have quantified the extent of hit we are going to take. That's understood. And then, a number of other clients have grown during Q1 also and they are in a ramp up stage, and they have contributed to wipe out the drop in Q1 also. So, we are going to see growth in those clients. Also in the product business, we think we will grow in Q2 compared to Q1. So, all of this put together, there is confidence that we'll grow in Q2.
Sure. What is your current outlook on employee addition for the full year?

From the employee addition point of view, what we have stated is we will be adding 30 to 35,000 gross during this particular year. And as far as quarter one is concerned, we have added 8,982 and we are on track.
So, what is the expected addition in 2Q, since the bulk of your pressure joinees have come in?

Overall, if you remember, last year we had offered 22,400-odd offers for the campus recruits, and they would be joining – some of them have joined and the rest of them would be joining through the rest of the year.

Great. Just one question and comment up for a follow-up later. SG&A, we have seen a significant drop this quarter. Do you expect SG&A to remain at current levels of percentage of revenue going into the year, or do you expect some increases as you continue to invest in the group?
Yes, I think, as I have said, we have focused on this cost containment program and we expect the results to continue to show.
Thanks, I'll come for a follow-up later, and all the best.
Thank you, Ms. Nagarajan. The next question is from the line of Mr. Julio Quinteros from Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.

Great, thanks. One of the things that just sort of jumps out of the numbers as I look at the net addition of new clients, it appears to be one of the lowest numbers. You guys have been running around 50 per quarter over the last couple of quarters. This quarter's number seems to be one of the lowest. Can you just talk a little bit about what that trajectory of the new clients would mean in terms of overall growth as you kind of think about this going forward?

Yes. I think it's a good question. Fundamentally there has been no change in terms of the quality of the clients we are adding. The large-scale clients, where we develop deep relationships, the client additions continue to be normal as we have had in the past quarters. We also have clients who are on a one-off project basis, and there has been a decrease in the addition of some of those clients where we add one-off projects. And I think other than this, we think the client addition is on course.

Is there a way to think about this – maybe even though there's less number of clients, are they – the number of the net new clients that are coming on line, are they potentially bigger clients? And is that why we shouldn't worry about it?

Yes, the point is right. See, actually, we have what is called a target universe. There is a set of companies that in each market we are targeting and then trying to win. And the net client addition that you see is from the target universe, and they are large companies where we expect to grow on a continuous basis. So, that's the reason I said you shouldn't worry.

Okay. And then just relative to the margin components, would it be possible to just walk through the pluses and the minuses on the operating margin level? There's a lot of different numbers. I just want to make sure I have gotten the data there correctly?

Yes, Julio, as I said, the operating margin, we started with plus 22.32 for last quarter and SG&A efficiencies contributed 2.17% positive. Foreign exchange impact was 2.3% positive, freight impact was 1.96% negative, pricing and productivity was 2.94% negative, onsite shift was 17 basis points negative and therefore, totally 26 basis points negative, making a Q1 '09 operating margin of 22.06%.
Great. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. Quinteros. The next question is from the line of Ms. Kanchana Vydianathan from Pacific Crest Securities. Please go ahead.

I guess my first question is, starting with respect to your large deal signing, in the past three quarters, you've continued to sign these large deals. Can you help us understand now, are these large deals, are they ramping up on track as to the way you expected or just given the economy, are you seeing a slowdown even in the ramp-up of these large deal?

No. The ramp-up is quite good. Actually, if you really look at the metrics, we announced a number of deals in the manufacturing sector last quarter, and in Q3. And you see the effect of that ramp-up, almost more than a 30% growth on a quarter-on-quarter basis on the manufacturing sector. And as you see, retail again, we've had a significant growth this quarter because the ramp-up is happening in both in the deal we announced in the UK last quarter and also in the deal we announced in the US in Q3 last year. So the ramp-ups are happening, all of those are on track. Also we will see such kind of ramp-up in the utility sector on the deals we announced towards the end of last quarter. The initial phase is over in Q1. So we expect to see that ramp-up producing results in Q2.

Okay. Thank you. One other question, I guess, with respect to -as the quarter progresses and as you continue to have conversations with the clients, can you help us understand, did anything change during the course of the quarter where the tone with the clients and even the decision making process, did it accelerate during the quarter and then again, are you seeing a slowdown? Or I guess if you were to compare, in the month of March, what happened in June, and even right now, what are you seeing? I mean, are you a little more positive now? Or are you still feeling the same, with respect to delays in client decision-making?

I think there are two points I want to make. The good news to us is that we identified issues with the two clients. And then the demerger of the European bank was also very well known. And the issues we had in the financial services sector clients stayed with these clients. No new issues we identified. So, to that extent it was as anticipated. The other side, the caution is that the financial services industry is still in a turmoil in the US. So if – are we sure that there will not be any specific client situations? We can't answer that question. As of today, we have not identified any other specific situation with any other client. So to that extent, we are confident.

Are you seeing, with respect to the slowdown, are you experiencing any such slowdown in any of the other verticals, and also if you were to look at Europe, are you seeing any impact from those regions as well, except--?

I think interestingly, if you look at Europe – even in this quarter, if you look at the deck that we have put out on the Web, there are deals we have announced even in the financial services sector and those deals have come from Europe. So even in the financial services sector, we are seeing deals getting closed. So we have announced three deals will be – in that segment in the – as part of the deck. As we said, we are continuing to see wins across other sectors. In total, we closed 12 large deals during Q1, three of which is above $75 million. So I think barring the caution that Ram said, and I also articulated again, with specific client situations that may arise that we don't know of. I think it's all right.
Okay. Thank you very much. That's all I have.
Thank you, Ms. Vydianathan. The next question is from the line of Mr. Pankaj Kapoor from ABN AMRO. Please go ahead.

Yeah. Hi, Chandra. First a couple of questions on the three clients you mentioned. You spoke of two turning the corner and one European bank which is still in the researching mode. Is it right, or is this client included in the two who have turned the corner?

No, there are the three clients. The two – the two clients on the European bank. These three too we expect to grow during Q2. In one of them, we will have issues. See, you should also know that the European bank is going to restructuring. We will start this procedure at three different clients going forward.
Okay. So that one in which we are sourcing issues, is it a client in which we have been facing problems for the last two quarter?

No. This problem, we started towards the end of Q4 and we did say it in the analyst call that we are seeing problems with this clients. There will be – there is likely to be a ramp down and that happened in Q1, and is going to continue in Q2. We think that somewhere in the middle of Q2, we should be through with that. But we have quantified exactly what we – we had discussions with the client. We exactly know what their focus area is, what is it that they are dropping in terms of projects, discretionary spend, so that's quantified.

And just next on the pricing environment, you spoke of stability and you're seeing that the stability may continue happening. One of the factors you have mentioned is that the asset leverage solutions sales was slower this quarter, which led to the overall pricing decline. You're saying that going forward, this class again may see lower spend given the uncertainties that we have. So the pricing may be still continued and under pressure even going forward?

No, I don't think so, because it must been seen in light of the revenues increases we have had in the product business in Q4. So if you really look at it, we did have a growth in the asset leverage solutions from Q3 to Q4, and then it did drop this quarter for the reasons I explained. We think from the current levels, it will grow.
So should it be right to assume that the blended pricing actually see a peak from now going forward from the current levels?

I think, it is definitely stable at these levels. And, you know, we don't give absolute numbers, but from this level, because all of the time and material contract that we have, there is no decline at all in pricing. So I think at this level, it will be stable. And if we managed to win a lot of transformation business going forward, then it can see a positive bias, but not at this point.

Okay. And I had just one question on the cost management. I was just trying to understand that what is the rationale which is driving this, given that the currency is already giving us some leverage. So in this environment, while we are cutting out on the SG&A expenses instead of probably reinvesting it into the business. So can you just help us understand what's driving the rationale behind the cost cutting and where do you see this moving forward?

You know, we have a fairly good position in that. It is really on the administrative aspect that we are cutting down. We are not cutting down on any of the selling or pre-selling activities. So that we are fairly clear about and we have had events and so on even in the last quarter where we continue to drive. And the new structure itself is focusing on a lot of selling orientations. And therefore, the success of this program has been – these are quite reasonably good because the – it has been reasonably good because in spite of increasing our focus on the selling activity, we are able to ensure that we hit a much better reduction in the other costs. Also, the new organizational structure brings in certain amount of consolidations and that eventually is driving also the cost reduction.
Thank you, Mr. Kapoor. The next question is from the line of Mr. Anthony Miller from Arete Research. Please go ahead.

Thank you very much. Well, I've got one question in two parts, so you can spread it among yourselves as you wish. But, one, first of all, on the banking products business, that you said suffered delays in the quarter, yet Infosys, they saw their banking products business expand in the quarter. And I can't quite reconcile the two. Why do you think that was?

Yes, I can talk about our pipeline. And in some of the deals that we are pursuing in the developed markets, that have been delays in decision-making in this quarter and that's what we have experienced. And having said that, we are very bullish about the opportunities for the banking products business. We have a large portfolio of that product. So we expect to see an update, but in this quarter, we did face delays in decision making, that's for sure.
Were you losing business to Infosys in particularly in the banking products?
Not that I know of during this quarter.

Okay. My second question is on BPO. We've had a couple of big BPO deals in the UK which were awarded recently. Obviously, there's the big one at Aviva, which WNS won, and then very recently, NHS Choice, which went to Capita. Now, I do know that TCS did throw its hat into the ring on NHS Choice. Can you let us know whether you were bidding for the Aviva business? And more generally, how your BPO, particularly your U.K. BPO business, is progressing, because other than Sun Life, we haven't really have seen – seen much since?

First of all, to answer your first question, in general, we do not talk about specific clients or specific deals for both confidentiality reasons and also for competitive reasons. So we do not talk about specific clients or specific deals.

Overall, if you look at the BPO business, the strategy that we articulated is going on extremely well. We had three important elements. One is, we don't do voice business. We predominantly do processing work. Second one is, we look for integrated IT and transaction processing opportunities. Third one is the platform play. And apart from the insurance platform, we have announced our HR platform. It is gaining a lot of traction. And we are on the verge of closing two or three deals where we have been short listed under the contract negotiation. So we should be announcing some deals in the BPO platforms going forward.
